title: 113_s2952
content: The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2014" establishes the "Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking" in the executive branch. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking is comprised of 15 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Minority Leader of the House. Appointments include individuals with expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by various leaders, with expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, database management, confidentiality, privacy, economics, statistics, program evaluation, and data security. Members are appointed based on specific criteria outlined for each appointing authority. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking appoints members with expertise in economics, statistics, program evaluation, data security, confidentiality, or database management. The President selects the chairperson, the Speaker of the House selects the co-chairperson, appointments must be made within 45 days of enactment, members serve without pay, and are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking appoints members with expertise in economics, statistics, program evaluation, data security, confidentiality, or database management. The duties of the Commission are outlined in Section 4. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will conduct a study on data inventory, infrastructure, and protocols related to Federal policymaking. Recommendations will be made on integrating data for program evaluation and policy research, modifying data infrastructure, and incorporating outcomes measurement into program design. Consideration will be given to creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data. The Commission will consider creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data, evaluating relevant datasets, legal barriers, data-sharing infrastructure, funding, access for researchers, limitations on data use, privacy protection, and utilization of research results. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations on protecting information, using research results to improve program design, and incentivizing interagency data sharing. The report must be submitted within 15 months of the majority of Commission members being appointed. The Commission members are appointed according to section 3. The term "administrative data" refers to information generated or collected by an agency for a Federal program, including various measures and indicators defined in title 31, United States Code. The Commission operates according to section 5 and has specific powers. The Commission advises various agencies, holds meetings within 30 days of majority appointment, and establishes rules of procedure with member approval. The Commission, with member approval, establishes rules of procedure including a quorum requirement. It may hold hearings, contract with agencies, use the United States mails, accept gifts, and be administered by the National Academy of Public Administration. Funding is subject to availability. The National Academy of Public Administration administers the Commission. Funding, not to exceed $2,000,000, is provided by principal statistical agencies at the request of the Census Director for the Commission's operations. The term "principal statistical agency" is defined in a report by the Office of Management and Budget. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the chairperson and co-chairperson, with staff appointed as needed. Experts and consultants may be hired at specified rates. The Commission will terminate within 18 months of the Act's enactment.
